block.p: Sharon and Abbas Pledge To Move Toward Peace Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel pledged to dismantle some ''unauthorized outposts'' in the West Bank, as President Bush defined his new role in the Middle East peace process, while Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, declared, ''the armed intifada must end.''
Thousands of Israelis, many of them settlers, denounced the Palestinian state as sketched by Mr. Sharon. And militant Palestinian groups said they would not lay down their arms.

Intelligence on Iraq Defended The Pentagon's top policy adviser refuted accusations that policy makers had politicized intelligence to justify war to topple Saddam Hussein, but would not comment on criticism that intelligence exaggerated the threat of Iraq's weapons.

Iraqi political leaders are actively trying to circumvent the occupation model proposed by the American administrator, L. Paul Bremer III, questioning the legality of his action and saying that an extended occupation would turn the Iraqi population against allied forces.

Human Smuggling Rings Broken President Vicente Fox of Mexico is cracking down on groups that have made immigrant smuggling Mexico's second-most profitable criminal enterprise and one that has caused a rising death toll along the border with the United States.

Liberian President Indicted President Charles Taylor of Liberia was indicted on war crimes charges by a special court in Sierra Leone, which accused him of responsibility for murders, mutilations and rapes in his country.

Russia Unclear on Iranian Plans President Vladimir V. Putin has voiced concern over allegations that Iran is conducting a secret nuclear-weapons program, but Russia's top nuclear official denied the country had pledged to suspend a shipment of nuclear fuel to Iran.

House Votes to Outlaw An Abortion Technique The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation outlawing what abortion opponents call ''partial birth abortion,'' putting the movement near a big victory.
Marijuana Grower Gets One Day A convicted marijuana grower from San Francisco was sentenced to one day in prison and fined $1,000 by a federal judge, the most lenient sentence allowed under law.
Democratic Research Group A group of Democrats are forming a new research institute in an effort to counter what they see as the domination of the national political debate by conservatives.

New Phase for the Clintons Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is riding the wave of a big publicity campaign for her new book, which is both the memoir of a former first lady and the latest chapter of the Clintons' public life.

Child Tax Credit Debated Senators from both parties, under pressure to provide an increased child tax credit to minimum-wage families, engaged in fierce negotiation over a proposed agreement that would also satisfy Republican demands to extend the credit to families making $150,000 a year.
Low-Cost Prescription Drugs A group of senators said they would push legislation to give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs.

Ocean Policies Criticized A private commission of scientists, fishermen and elected officials called for big changes in federal ocean policies to curb harm to America's marine resources from coastal building, polluted runoff and what the panel described as destructive fishing practices.

Mayor Cancels Service Cuts As Way to Trim Budget Mayor Bloomberg backed away from $90.2 million in budget cuts, abandoning plans to reduce trash pickups outside Manhattan, curtail library hours and slash a summer jobs program.

States Sue E.P.A. on Car Fumes Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts sued the Environmental Protection Agency, saying carbon dioxide emissions from cars and power plants should be regulated because they contribute to global warming.

Toll Rollback Ordered A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to roll back toll increases on several bridges and tunnels, saying that the authority had deliberately misled the public about its finances.
Spurs Win Game 1 San Antonio beat the New Jersey Nets, 101-89, in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals.
School Spending Increase New York State voters approved increases in school spending.

Stewart Pleads Not Guilty Martha Stewart was indicted on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud. After pleading not guilty, Ms. Stewart stepped down as chairwoman and chief executive of her company.
Senate to Challenge F.C.C. A bipartisan majority of an important Senate committee indicated that it would vote to overturn some of the new media ownership rules adopted two days ago by the F.C.C.
